Silence is Golden

06/04/2012

The Dickens Before Sound event was a success, showing that the original adaptations of the author's work still hold their own against their modern counterparts.

Image by

By undefined undefined

York Literature Festival 2012, Day 4: Sunday 1 April Venue: City Screen Time: 5.30pm Great Expectations, Bleak House and Oliver Twist are just a few of Dickens' classic stories that have been recently adapted to the screen. However, long before the advent of Multiplex Cinemas and television, before Technicolor and blockbusters; and even before the invention of the 'Talkies,' Dickens was being adapted to motion pictures. It would be easy to be sceptical about how effective Charles Dickens' work would be, when transferred onto the silent, silver screen. The accents and dialects in which Dickens' characters spoke, were always fundamental to their characters and the way in which they are portrayed by the reader. Nevertheless, in the year of the author's bicentenary, the 'Dickens before Sound' event aimed to show how his stories and characters were just as well portrayed on the big screen one hundred years ago; as they are in modern film and television today. The evening was introduced by Andrew Higson who, through his encyclopaedic knowledge of silent films, was able to offer interesting insights into how the films were put together; and also contextualised the films according to their place within cinematic history. Almost 100 silent films were made, drawing on the stories and the characters that Dickens had created. Although around two thirds of these films have been lost, many still remain, if only in a fragmented form. Higson spoke of how 'The Cricket on the Hearth' (1909), one of the first ever 'feature-length' movies, had survived for years on paper in the Library of Congress and had, only recently, been transferred back on to film. Higson's explanations and the films being shown in chronological order enabled the audience to see the vast improvements made in cinema before sound came along. The first film that was shown was based on the character Gabriel Grub who was depicted by Dickens in Chapter 29 of The Pickwick Papers. The adaptation (from the late 19th century) was on magic lantern slides; a very popular media method at the time; and consisted of beautiful, colourful, hand painted images that dissolved into one another. The pictures were accompanied by a lecturer telling the story. Though very simplistic in terms of our high expectations today, this method was, at the time, very advanced and effective in appealing to the general (and often illiterate) public, who otherwise would have never experienced the marvels of Dickens' work. This first piece of cinema shown, contrasted greatly to the last two pieces; which were versions of Nicholas Nickleby and David Copperfield, 1912 and 1913 respectively. At this time, as Higson animatedly explained, the world of cinema was trying to entice the middle class audience by creating feature-length films of respectable books. Both of these films use grand sets, and the story lines can be understood with little or no knowledge of the characters prior to watching the films. The film of David Copperfield was particularly beautiful and powerful. It was clear that very little had been lost from Dickens' original novel in this adaptation. The most notable and intriguing clip of the collection was, for me, the 1909 version of Scrooge, of which only four minutes have survived. But the secret of the success as to why Dickens could be so successfully adapted onto the silent screen was plainly obvious in this clip. It lies in the strength of the characters that he created. The larger than life characters seemed to work harmoniously with the melodramatic style of acting that was so prominent at the time. Scrooge, though only short in length, captured the audience through the way in which the scene had been set up as though it was a stage in a theatre; thus instantly drawing the viewers in. The use of even basic cinematography tricks such as the double exposure of film to create the ghostly images, successfully illustrated the rich visual imagery that one gets when reading a Dickens novel. The short pieces of cinema were thoroughly enjoyable, and it became clear that watching a whole feature film 'before sound' and any other special effects, could be just as gripping as watching a modern day, coloured adaptation that included the computerised additions.
